channel.title: How-To Geek
channel.description: We explain technology. Learn more with our articles, reviews, tips, and the best answers to your most pressing tech questions.

item.title: LineageOS 23, Based on Android 16, Is Finally Here
item.dc:creator: Arol Wright
item.description: At a time when the custom ROM scene looks increasingly dire.
item.content:encoded: Custom ROMs still exist, even as you might not be popping into our sister site XDA-Developers to download them as often as you used to do. LineageOS remains one of the most popular projects out there, and now, it's finally getting updated to Android 16—with some notes that reflect just how dire things have gotten.

item.title: 7 Open-Source Apps That Will Let You Cancel Pricey Subscriptions
item.dc:creator: Tim Brookes
item.description: Sometimes the best option is free.
item.content:encoded: There’s almost certainly a good open-source alternative for most apps and services you depend on. Not all of them are comparable to paid software, and some require significant setup or technical knowledge, but all are worth considering.

item.title: Why I Install My Steam Games on a Portable SSD
item.dc:creator: Sydney Butler
item.description: Don't leave your old SSDs in the drawer, they want to come out and play.
item.content:encoded: Over the years, the Steam client has become exceptionally flexible when it comes to managing your game files, and that includes game installations on external drives. It's as simple as plugging in your drive, and adding it as a library under the "Storage" section of Steam's settings.

item.title: 7 Tech Products I'd Never Buy Refurbished
item.dc:creator: Sydney Butler
item.description: I guess I have trust issues.
item.content:encoded: I love a good used gadget deal, and I have no issue buying stuff from places like Facebook marketplace for a good bargain, but when it comes to "refurbished" products you're often getting nothing more than an exterior wipe-down of the device and a very limited discount versus buying the same thing new.

item.title: Don’t Mix Keycap Sets Until You Read This
item.dc:creator: Ismar Hrnjicevic
item.description: Who knew there were rules to mixing keycaps?
item.content:encoded: If you have a mechanical keyboard, you’ve probably thought about mixing keycap sets—whether it’s a few accent keys or a full mix, it’s a fun way to make your board unique. However, before you begin, let’s go over a few key points to ensure your mix is just right.

item.title: I Made These Home Assistant Rookie Mistakes So You Don't Have To
item.dc:creator: Adam Davidson
item.description: Be smarter about your smart home than I was.
item.content:encoded: Home Assistant is powerful open-source smart home software that can control and automate a huge number of smart devices. Unlike popular smart home ecosystems such as Alexa and Siri, Home Assistant isn't locked to any specific devices or protocols; you can use it with virtually any smart home device you want.

item.title: TV Lies, Scandals, and Meltdowns—10 Movies That Got It Right
item.dc:creator: Mark McPherson
item.description: These are the movies that heightened the attraction of the small screen for the big screen.
item.content:encoded: Television has the power to entertain and inform, but it’s a medium driven mainly by what audiences want to watch. Something controversial or provocative, whether a rousing season finale or an important historical event, can easily become a ratings hit. The allure has made television both essential for our understanding of the world and fragile because of how easily it can be manipulated.

item.title: Why I Don’t Use Safari on My Mac
item.dc:creator: Bobby Jack
item.description: Why not browse for an alternative?
item.content:encoded: I don't use Safari on my Mac; I use Chrome instead. I'm frequently tempted to make the switch—I generally prefer using the default or ‘official’ app, especially on macOS because everything tends to integrate so well. But I'm sticking with Chrome; here’s why.

item.title: How to Block Internet Access for Specific Android Apps
item.dc:creator: Faisal Rasool
item.description: A simple way to improve privacy, battery life, and data savings.
item.content:encoded: About a decade ago, I used to daily drive a custom Android ROM called CynanogenMod. In its settings app, there were in-built switches for cutting off any app’s internet access. Sadly, native Android still doesn’t have this feature, even in the latest version 16 update. Let me show you a workaround and why you might want to use it.

item.title: PS VR2 Could’ve Saved 3D Movies—But Sony Blew It
item.dc:creator: Sydney Butler
item.description: Am I the only one that liked 3D movies?
item.content:encoded: Believe it or not, the first ever 3D movie I saw was the original Avatar, and boy did that set a high bar for what 3D movies can be. During the peak of the last 3D movie fad, it was mainly a cinema experience for me. 3D TVs and Blu-rays were just too expensive for me back then, but these days people can hardly give their 3D movies away.
